Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 767, 560]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 644, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 698, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the spring constant \(k\) of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 133, 757, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 414, 532, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 146, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 920, 480]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is fixed in position close to the spring. **Do not change the position of the metre rule.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 181, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 491, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
Use the set-square provided to take readings from the metre rule in order to determine the length \(l_0\) of the coiled part of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 537, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
Record of readings taken ........................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<form>(1)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 600, 180, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Record in Table 1.1 the value of the length of the spring \(l_0\) when the load \(L\) is 0.00N. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 631, 180, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 631, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
• Place a load of 0.20N on the spring. Record in Table 1.1 the new length \(l\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 678, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
• Use the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\) to calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring. Record the value of \(e\) in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 724, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the procedure using loads of 0.40N, 0.60N, 0.80N and 1.00N. Record all the readings and results in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 42, 509, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 102, 683, 280]]<|/det|>
\(L/\mathrm {N}\)\(l/\mathrm {mm}\)\(e/\mathrm {mm}\)
0.000
0.20
0.40
0.60
0.80
1.00
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 281, 920, 300]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 148, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 576, 331]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(L / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(e / \mathrm{mm}\) (x-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 339, 791, 757]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 144, 803]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 920, 819]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 907, 920, 926]]<|/det|>
G = .............................................................[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 653, 89]]<|/det|>
The gradient \(G\) is numerically equal to the spring constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 863, 120]]<|/det|>
Write down a value for \(k\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ............................................ N/mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 164, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 599, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the power of lamps.

The circuit shown in Fig. 2.1 has been set up for you.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 129, 609, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 280, 532, 299]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 312, 282, 330]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 342, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) across the lamps and the current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 432, 920, 453]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 907, 500]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{T}}\) produced by the lamp filaments, using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{T}} = V_{\mathrm{T}}I_{\mathrm{T}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 572, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
<form>\(P_{\mathrm{T}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 792, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{X}}\) across lamp X and the current \(I_{\mathrm{X}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 147, 920, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 179, 920, 201]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 225, 183, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 893, 246]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{X}}\) produced by the lamp filament using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{X}} = V_{\mathrm{X}}I_{\mathrm{X}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 317, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
\[P_{\mathrm{X}} = ............................................................ [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 144, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 789, 368]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter. Reconnect the voltmeter across lamp Y. Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 181, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{Y}}\) across lamp Y and the current \(I_{\mathrm{Y}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 427, 918, 448]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{Y}} = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 458, 920, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 185, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 893, 523]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{Y}}\) produced by the lamp filament using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{Y}} = V_{\mathrm{Y}}I_{\mathrm{Y}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 581, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
\[P_{\mathrm{Y}} = ............................................................ [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 146, 631]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
State and explain briefly whether your two values for power, \(P_{\mathrm{X}}\) and \(P_{\mathrm{Y}}\) are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 917, 678]]<|/det|>
statement ............................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 917, 709]]<|/det|>
explanation ............................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 739, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 660, 89]]<|/det|>
Draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit rearranged so that:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 485, 120]]<|/det|>
• the lamps are connected in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 648, 151]]<|/det|>
• the ammeter will measure the total current in the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 630, 182]]<|/det|>
• the voltmeter will measure the p.d. across the lamps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 479, 213]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 913, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the refractive index \(n\) of the material of a transparent block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 101, 821, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 630, 532, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 144, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 660, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 707, 175, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 707, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 753, 173, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 753, 574, 771]]<|/det|>
Draw and label the outline of the block **ABCD**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 785, 171, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw the normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**. Continue the normal so that it passes through side **CD** of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 831, 171, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 831, 526, 848]]<|/det|>
Label the point **F** where **NL** crosses **AB**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 863, 173, 880]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 863, 529, 880]]<|/det|>
Label the point **G** where **NL** crosses **CD**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 875, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 73, 777, 92]]<|/det|>
Draw the line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 175, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 104, 472, 123]]<|/det|>
Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 175, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 135, 881, 154]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 166, 173, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 166, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 175, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 228, 918, 262]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}, \mathsf{P}_{4},\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2},\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 175, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 274, 524, 293]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}, \mathsf{P}_{2}, \mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 175, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 305, 457, 324]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 336, 173, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 336, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 175, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 383, 638, 402]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 175, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 413, 737, 432]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]
